prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have already targeted four of these objects (NGC 4945, NGC 1365, M83, Circinus) with the ATCA in the HCN(1-0) line, so we know that the emission peaks in the 50-80 mJy range in an 8'' beam (see Fig. 1 and 2). The weaker lines of our survey are about 5 times fainter than HCN and to get a S/N of 5 we therefore aim at a rms of 2 mJy. 3 km/s channels are adequate for deriving the kinematics of the gas - if the emission turns out to be fainter than this, such a setting will allow us to still increase the signal-to-noise ratio by significant spectral smoothing. The widest correlator setup with a ~2 km/s resolution features a bandwidth of ~930MHz which is large enough to cover the full suite of transitions simultaneously (spectral smoothing of 2). To match the ATCA observations and for better surface brightness sensitivity, we request the observations to be performed at about 3'' resolution. CO is much brighter and we request a 5 times larger rms of ~10mJy in a ~1km/s channel to obtain the spectral resolution that is also adequate for absorption studies against the bright central cores.

To match the ATCA observations and for better surface brightness sensitivity, we request the observations to be performed at about 3'' resolution. CO is much brighter and we request a 5 times larger rms of ~10mJy in a ~1km/s channel to obtain the spectral resolution that is also adequate for absorption studies against the bright central cores.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Starburst and active galaxies are the powerhouses of the Universe. They return large amounts of mechanical energy, mass, metals, and UV radiation into their surroundings in the form of strong galactic winds and jets. The influence of feedback is now the most important but least understood ingredient of galaxy formation theories. We propose to use ALMA to map molecular lines toward five prominent starburst galaxies with and without AGN, with a large range of star formation rates, from 'regular' starbursts, to IR-luminous galaxies, and with early and late type morphologies. Building upon previous ATCA maps of ammonia and HCN, we request CO observations to derive the detailed morphologies and kinematics of the nuclear regions of these galaxies to derive the details of the starburst feeding with cold gas. We also propose to obtain maps of molecular tracers for high densities, photon- and X-ray dominated regions, shocks, and excitation of the imminently star forming gas. The data will provide a unique and almost complete characterization of the molecular gas that supplies the starburst with fresh material but is under the strong influence of the feedback generated in the nucleus.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Domenici Science Operations Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Physics, New Mexico Tech
Department of Physics, New Mexico Tech
